data.title: grave
data.meta_description: GRAVE meaning: 1. a place in the ground where a dead person is buried:  2. seriously bad:  3. a place in the…. Learn more.
data.text:
noun [ C ]

grave noun [C] (BURYING PLACE)

B1 us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ɡreɪv/ uk

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ɡreɪv/

a place in the ground where a dead person is buried:

mass grave Most of the victims' bodies were found in a mass grave.

unmarked grave He was buried in an unmarked grave in the prison cemetery.

a grave digger

He visits his mother's grave every Sunday.

More examplesFewer examples

They lowered the coffin into the grave.

She died penniless and was buried in an unmarked grave.

One can only hope that his unquiet spirit found some peace in the grave.

Sometimes I think these children are going to drive me to an early grave!

Many of the soldiers were interred in unmarked graves.

grave

adjective

us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ɡreɪv/ uk

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ɡreɪv/

a grave situation

Synonym

Thesaurus: synonyms, antonyms, and examples

seriousHer condition is not thought to be serious.

badHe got a bad case of food poisoning.

bigOnline fraud is a big problem.

majorIt's not a major problem, but it does need to be taken care of.

graveThe public is in grave danger.

See more results »

Related word

grave

us

/ɡreɪv/

grave adjective [-er/-est only] (SERIOUS)

gravely

adverb us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈɡreɪv·li/

She is gravely ill.

(Definition of grave from the Cambridge Academic Content Dictionary © Cambridge University Press)

Examples of grave

grave

In the back, a woman stood motionless, staring relentlessly upon the graves and surrounding lush field.

And here, lobstering is serious business: battles for fishing territory can get ugly, and illegal harvesting is a grave offense.

I have put five people in the grave.

He showed them the grave he had dug up.

Police found a shovel thought to have been used to dig up the grave.

The hunt has uncovered nine mass graves containing the remains of 30 other missing people.

Graves said she stayed strong during the five months she cared for her husband.

As far as we can tell, his grave has not become a pilgrimage site.

Delicately -- reverently -- he places it on top of the grave.

However, human remains or any object from a grave may not be touched or shown.

Graves wanted to keep it a secret until all the paperwork was completed.

Your mind is incredibly powerful and can see you through the gravest of situations.

She says no one's ever taken her across the street to visit the grave.

These examples are from corpora and from sources on the web. Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.

Collocations with grave

grave

These are words often used in combination with grave.

Click on a collocation to see more examples of it.

ancient grave

The total area is 38.63 km. is a cluster of ancient grave caves dug on the cliff made of tuff.

From

Wikipedia

common grave

I have already explained that there is nothing degrading or improper about burial in a common grave of patients who have died in hospital.

grave disease
